Award.AwardTitle: A Science-Policy Interface in the Global South: Climate-Change Decision Making in Brazil

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
For nearly two decades, scientists worldwide have engaged in resource-intensive efforts to produce scientific evidence and a succession of assessment reports on the state of the global environment. In the meantime, little attention has been paid to whether or not intended audiences are receptive to them, and to understanding the factors conditioning or undermining such receptivity. Focused on the role of science, power and politics in Brazilian climate policy formation, this research project funded by the Science and Society Program uses ethnographic and policy network methods to identify and analyze the science-policy interface. It examines the weight and meaning given by different, climate-involved actors and social networks to different kinds and sources of scientific knowledge, and how these actors seek to manage science to ensure its perceived reliability and protect political interests. It centrally probes the practical considerations and socio-cultural, political and structural factors that bear on decision makers' science and policy choices, and the relative credibility they give to sources that are variously foreign, international or national, governmental or non-governmental. The project subsumes the PI's involvement in "Compon", an international collaborative effort to produce and compare studies in 17 countries on the role of social networks and science in climate decision making. The research also includes preliminary field-site investigation in Argentina.

Intellectual merit: The research advances theoretical and practical understanding of the science-policy interface in general, and in Latin America and Brazil in particular, contributing to policy, science and environmental studies, anthropology and international relations. The research fills large knowledge gaps related to the role of science in environmental policy making in general, and in Brazil in particular, a country whose climate-related decision making is highly consequential internationally, politically and environmentally. It contributes to a new initiative to make "Earth System Governance" a central, cross-cutting theme under the major global change research programs, and, through Compon, promises to push Earth System Governance research past isolated and difficult to compare case studies towards rigorous, inter-comparative analysis of knowledge and decision making systems in a wide range of national contexts.

Broader Impacts: The study identifies global, regional, national and sub-national patterns of science-policy structures and dynamics, including problems in the production, framing and flow of knowledge that weaken environmental protection in the face of climate change. This knowledge is used to identify the circumstances under which science is and is not deemed relevant and credible by decision makers, with view to improving the effectiveness of science through resource allocation and science-policy interface changes. Insights from the research are brought to bear in multiple contexts through peer-reviewed publications, collaborations, conference and seminar presentations, internet sites and web logs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Outcomes report for Award 0751258 (P.I. Myanna Lahsen)

“A Science-Policy Interface in the Global South: Climate Change Decision Making in Brazil”

The project has yielded published analyses revealing obstacles in the science-policy interface in Brazil due to Brazilian policy makers’ limited trust in environmental science.  It subsumed international collaboration under COMPON (www.compon.org), which is generating international comparisons of national positions and politics related to climate in the Americas, Europe and Asia. As part of COMPON, the project has (1) accumulated extensive questionnaire data from 100 key actors in Brazilian climate policy and politics and (2) analyzed climate coverage in major Brazilian daily newspapers from (2005-2014).

The analysis of newspaper coverage in major Brazilian daily newspapers (2002-2014) discovered that climate change is overwhelmingly framed as an energy problem in Brazil, even though agriculture and land use together are the main source of Brazil´s greenhouse gas emissions and a credible study concludes that meat production might be responsible for approximately half of them.  Considering, in addition, that international polls consistently show Brazilians to care strongly about climate change and biodiversity loss, one might expect national newspaper discussions focused on meat. By contrast, this analysis revealed that such discussions hardly exist in Brazil. This finding – as yet unpublished - has the potential to generate public debate about this suppressed issue and to bring into the light the importance of extending attention to media policy and political economic factors as central obstacles to climate policy.

The analysis focused centrally on Folha de Sao Paulo and O Globo, respectively first and second in national circulation. It also studied Valor Economico and Estado de Sao Paulo, but access via the Factiva database was limited to articles from 2002-2009 and 2002-2011, respectively.

Climate change mentioning articles were subjected to keyword searches and content analysis. These showed that even only references to renewable energy received much greater emphasis compared to meat, also when including variant terms (livestock and cow). From 2007-2014, the number of references to meat in Folha de Sao Paulo never went above 12. Rather than increase in recent years in line with the increasing scientific and political calls for diet meatification, Folha de Sao Paulo´s references to meat dropped to zero in 2014. The same overall tendencies were evident in O Globo, O Estado de Sao Paulo, and Valor Economico.  In all newspapers, with few exceptions, references to meat as a problem were superficial and passing in nature, and often tended to concentrate in one or two articles annually. In Folha de Sao Paulo in both 2011 and 2013, for instance, the references to meat were largely concentrated in a single article specifically about foreign efforts to produce artificial meat from stem cells, efforts relatively far removed from Brazilian realities and responsibilities.

Social, political and economic factors underpin the newspapers’ disinclination to discuss meat as a problem. These factors were explored by means of a multi-methods approach, including interviews with Brazilian journalists and scientists. Aside from the fact that meat is a cherished part of the diet in Brazil with important inflections of culture and class, causes of the lacking critical discussion of meat are tied to strong, interwoven financial and political interests in the meat industry, which also influence national government and communications media.
